elements.text: What can happen when we try something new?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Written by Mem Fox and Judy Horacek

This narrative follows a mother duck and her ducklings as they cross a bridge. When her ducklings fall over the edge, what will Mother Duck do? There are many opportunities to use the ducklings to count, add, subtract, and discuss location.

Focus on Operations: Have children use their fingers to help them count the ducklings on and below the bridge.
More little ducks keep coming onto the bridge! First there was one. Now there are two.
Who can come and count the little ducks in the bottom picture? How many little ducks are there now?
One duck fell into the river

There were five little ducks on the bridge. Then there was a lot of wind, which knocked one duck off of the bridge. Let’s count back one from five to say how many little ducks are still on the bridge.
Another little duck toppled off the bridge and into the river!
How many are in the river now? Let’s count one more than one.
With two little ducks in the river, how many are still on the bridge? There were five little ducks. Then two fell. Let’s count back two from five to find out.
Were we right? Are there three ducks left on the bridge? Who can come up and count them?
Let’s count the little ducks on the bridge again in a different order. Are there still three?
Mother Duck flew into the river! Is she having fun? Do you have fun when you join an activity with your family or friends?
Let’s talk about this question: What does Mother Duck do when her ducklings fall into the water?

She flies into the river with them.

Reading with an adult who can model the reading process is crucial in building children’s early literacy. Children learn that text has meaning by watching you read it. As you read aloud important words in texts, such as number words and key vocabulary, run your finger below the word to show where and how you are reading the letters.
Share the Mind Builder: Play With Others

Everyone loves to play. Sometimes, playing is more fun when we play together. We can make new friends and work together to do something bigger and more exciting than we could do alone. There are lots of ways to play together, but it’s always important to be kind and respectful. What are some ways you could have fun playing together with your classmates?
Today we will reread some pages of
by Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. We will talk about how the ducklings play together.
Clifford loves to play with friends! He also likes reading stories about friends and family who play together.

Playing together may look different for children at this age depending on the stage of development. For younger preschoolers, parallel (playing alongside another child) and associative (playing the same game, but without interacting) play may be more common than directly joining a group. Encourage and praise all levels of peer play. (Guralnick, 1993)

Preschoolers tend to best understand spatial awareness by moving their own bodies, such as by standing

. However, it’s important for children to explore spatial concepts in multiple ways. Provide many opportunities for children to use location words, from giving directions to experimenting with classroom objects.

Play a game of Simon Says with stretching. As Simon, tell children to stretch using numbers and varying the counting order. For example:
Simon Says stretch all five fingers on one hand, starting with your thumb.
Simon Says stretch the same fingers, starting with your pinky
. Encourage children to count aloud as they stretch each finger. Continue the activity using arms and legs.
Provide a writing prompt about stretching before an activity. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

Colloquial phrases and idioms, such as “get tips,” can be confusing to children whose home language is not English. As you come across these phrases, be sure to take time to explain their meanings. You may want to pair multilingual children with a classmate who can explain what is meant, which will also help establish relationships and model teamwork.

Explain that the class is going to try something new. Teach the children something they haven’t done as a group before, like doing a few yoga poses, saying hello in other languages, or tasting an unfamiliar fruit or vegetable. Follow up with a brief discussion.
Was it scary to try something new? Was it fun? How do you feel now? Maybe this will encourage you to try something new in the future!

Lala wonders if you remember whether this book tells a story or teaches information. Do you know?
We have learned many ways we can try new things! When we read today, think about this question: What new things do the ducks try?
Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time we will act out parts of the story. We will also count the ducks as we read.
Let’s pretend to cross the bridge! I will be Mother Duck. Who will be the ducklings?
Have children line up on one side of the room and cross the room behind you one by one. Guide the group to count.
How many ducks are there in all?
One duckling gets swept up into the air! Let’s all pretend to be swept up. Spin around and lift your hands up high in the air!
One duckling is off the bridge! How many ducks are left?
More ducks fell into the river! They’re swimming in the water. Let’s all try swimming like ducks. Tuck your wings in tight and move your feet fast!
Two more ducklings are off the bridge! How many ducks are left?
More ducks looked over the edge and fell! Let’s pretend to peek down over the edge.
Ask the last two “ducklings” to leave.
Two more ducklings are off the bridge! How many are in the water? Who is left on the bridge?
Mother Duck is going to try flying into the water! Let’s all try to fly like Mother Duck. Step forward and back. Spread your wings!
Was it fun to act out the story together as a team?
What new things do the ducks try?
Have them share with the group.
The ducklings swim in the water.
Mother Duck flies into the water.

As children age, they begin to understand that numbers can represent quantities. Through repetition, they count objects and hear that the last number counted is the number of objects in that group. This is called cardinality. Reinforce the concept by pointing to objects as they are counted, showing one-to-one correspondence.
